articles.headline: Delay as the New Denial: The Latest Republican Tactic to Block Climate Action
articles.snippet: The party has largely moved beyond denying the existence of climate change but continues to oppose dramatic action to halt it, worried about the short-term economic consequences.
articles.abstract: The party has largely moved beyond denying the existence of climate change but continues to oppose dramatic action to halt it, worried about the short-term economic consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Lisa Friedman and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Bipartisan Senate Group Strikes Deal to Rewrite Electoral Count Act
articles.snippet: The changes outlined by the senators are intended to prevent a repeat of the effort on Jan. 6, 2021, to overturn the presidential election in Congress.
articles.abstract: The changes outlined by the senators are intended to prevent a repeat of the effort on Jan. 6, 2021, to overturn the presidential election in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators proposed new legislation on Wednesday to modernize the 135-year-old Electoral Count Act, working to overhaul a law that President Donald J. Trump tried to abuse on Jan. 6, 2021, to interfere with Congress’s certification of his election defeat.

articles.headline: With Russian Cutoff Feared, Europeans Are Told to Curb Natural Gas Use
articles.snippet: The European Union’s executive branch says member countries must cut consumption by 15 percent between now and the springtime to stave off a major crisis as Russia weaponizes its exports.
articles.abstract: The European Union’s executive branch says member countries must cut consumption by 15 percent between now and the springtime to stave off a major crisis as Russia weaponizes its exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Europe must cut its use of natural gas by 15 percent from now through next spring to prevent a major crisis as Russia slashes gas exports, the European Union’s executive branch said on Wednesday, calling for hard sacrifices by the people of the world’s richest group of nations.

articles.headline: China Fines Didi $1.2 Billion as Tech Sector Pressures Persist
articles.snippet: Regulators sought to make the company an example of the consequences of mishandling data — and of the grave political error of ignoring the authorities.
articles.abstract: Regulators sought to make the company an example of the consequences of mishandling data — and of the grave political error of ignoring the authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: In slapping China’s ride-hailing giant, Didi Global, with a record $1.2 billion fine for data breaches, Beijing made clear to the country’s internet companies that their freewheeling days were over.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and John Liu

articles.headline: Liz Cheney, Front and Center in the Jan. 6 Hearings, Pursues a Mission
articles.snippet: “I believe this is the most important thing I’ve ever done professionally,” she said, “and maybe the most important thing I ever do.”
articles.abstract: “I believe this is the most important thing I’ve ever done professionally,” she said, “and maybe the most important thing I ever do.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the House Jan. 6 committee is out with Covid-19. So after giving opening remarks by video when the panel convenes its final scheduled prime-time hearing of the summer on Thursday night, he will turn the gavel over to Representative Liz Cheney. But for all intents and purposes, it has been the Liz Cheney show all along.

articles.headline: A Recession Alarm Is Ringing on Wall Street
articles.snippet: An inversion of the bond market’s yield curve has preceded every U.S. recession for the past half century. It is happening again.
articles.abstract: An inversion of the bond market’s yield curve has preceded every U.S. recession for the past half century. It is happening again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s most-talked-about recession indicator is sounding its loudest alarm in two decades, intensifying concerns among investors that the U.S. economy is heading toward a slowdown.

articles.headline: Europe Joins Fight Against Inflation, Raising Rates for First Time in 11 Years
articles.snippet: Policymakers are trying to slow soaring prices while avoiding a recession among the countries that use the euro.
articles.abstract: Policymakers are trying to slow soaring prices while avoiding a recession among the countries that use the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — As consumer prices across Europe soar at the fastest rate in generations, officials in Frankfurt on Thursday took a powerful step to control rapid inflation amid mounting concerns over an economic slowdown.

articles.headline: Russia Restarts Gas Shipments Through Pipeline, but Keeps Germany Guessing
articles.snippet: Russia is again sending natural gas through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Germany, but nobody knows how much and how long the fuel will flow.
articles.abstract: Russia is again sending natural gas through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Germany, but nobody knows how much and how long the fuel will flow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s decision to restart the flow of natural gas through a vital pipeline on Thursday brought a moment of relief to Germany, which uses the fuel to power its most important industries and heat half its homes. But it is unlikely to be much more than that.

articles.headline: Amazon to acquire One Medical clinics in latest push into health care.
articles.snippet: The $3.9 billion deal is Amazon’s latest acquisition in the health care industry. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.
articles.abstract: The $3.9 billion deal is Amazon’s latest acquisition in the health care industry. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Just two months ago, Andy Jassy, almost a year into his reign as Amazon’s chief executive, told investors that driving down costs was a “really big area of focus,” after the company produced its worst quarterly earnings in years. But that didn’t mean he wasn’t open to a deal.

articles.headline: Biden Tests Positive for Virus and Is Experiencing Mild Symptoms
articles.snippet: The president tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday and is expected to isolate for at least five days before resuming normal activities.
articles.abstract: The president tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday and is expected to isolate for at least five days before resuming normal activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden tested positive on Thursday for the coronavirus, raising health concerns for the 79-year-old president and underscoring how the virus remains a persistent, if muted, threat in a country trying to put the pandemic in the past.

articles.headline: He Built a Home to Survive a Civil War. Tragedy Found Him Anyway.
articles.snippet: C. Wesley Morgan once believed that the place he built, which included a 2,000-square-foot bunker, was the safest house in Kentucky.
articles.abstract: C. Wesley Morgan once believed that the place he built, which included a 2,000-square-foot bunker, was the safest house in Kentucky.
